S5.T1.caption: Table 1. Statistics of datasets used in the experiments.
S5.T1.table:
Statistic Tb2014 Tb2015 Netflix Foursquare
No. of Users 8K 192K 301K 52K
No. of Items 39K 10K 9K 37K
No. of Interactions 749K 9M 49M 2M
Time Span 31 days 123 days 74 months 22 months
AER 35.5% 26.0% 58.4% 60.0%
references: We conduct experiments on four datasets (i.e., Neflix1 11 11https://academictorrents.com/details/9b13183dc4d60676b773c9e2cd6de5e5542cee9a, Foursquare2 22 22https://sites.google.com/site/yangdingqi/home/foursquare-dataset (Yang et al., 2019, 2020) and Taobao2014 (Yang et al., 2019, 2020) and Taobao20143 33 33https://tianchi.aliyun.com/dataset/46 and Taobao20154 44 44https://tianchi.aliyun.com/dataset/dataDetail?dataId=53 from from Alibaba’s M-Commerce platforms) from three different domains (i.e., social media, points-of-interests , and e-commerce). Following (He et al., 2023; Yang et al., 2019, 2020), we use the average entity overlapping rate (AER) between segments to assess data stream stability; higher AER indicates greater stability. Data in each segment is divided into training, validation, and test sets in an 8:1:1 ratio. The statistics of the four datasets are summarized in Table  (He et al., 2023; Yang et al., 2019, 2020), we use the average entity overlapping rate (AER) between segments to assess data stream stability; higher AER indicates greater stability. Data in each segment is divided into training, validation, and test sets in an 8:1:1 ratio. The statistics of the four datasets are summarized in Table 1.
